data.q: What does the 'Same-Origin Policy' (SOP) prevent in a browser?
o: It prevents users from visiting multiple websites at once
It restricts a script on one origin from interacting with a resource from another origin
It stops the browser from caching sensitive data
It prevents websites from using external CSS libraries
data.e: SOP is a fundamental security building block that ensures scripts from site A cannot access private data from site B (like cookies or DOM) unless explicitly permitted.

data.q: What is the purpose of 'Cross-Origin Resource Sharing' (CORS)?
o: To block all cross-site requests by default
To allow servers to specify which origins are permitted to access their resources
To encrypt data sent between the browser and the server
To speed up the loading of third-party scripts
data.e: CORS is a mechanism that uses additional HTTP headers to tell browsers to give a web application running at one origin access to selected resources from a different origin.

data.q: What is a 'Preflight Request' in the context of CORS?
o: A request sent to verify the user's password
An OPTIONS request sent by the browser to check if the actual request is safe to send
A background task that pre-loads images
A check to see if the user is connected to the internet
data.e: For 'non-simple' requests (like those with JSON or custom headers), the browser sends an OPTIONS request first to ensure the server understands and allows the cross-origin method.

data.q: Which security header is used to prevent 'Cross-Site Scripting' (XSS) by restricting where scripts can be loaded from?
o: X-Frame-Options
Strict-Transport-Security
Content-Security-Policy (CSP)
Referrer-Policy
data.e: CSP allows site administrators to declare which dynamic resources are allowed to load, effectively neutralizing most XSS attacks by blocking unauthorized scripts.

o: Stealing a user's password through a fake login page
Tricking a logged-in user's browser into sending an unauthorized request to a web application
Injecting malicious scripts into a database
A type of denial-of-service attack
data.e: CSRF exploits the fact that browsers automatically include credentials like cookies in requests, allowing a malicious site to perform actions on behalf of a user on a different site.

data.q: Which cookie attribute helps prevent CSRF attacks by controlling when cookies are sent with cross-site requests?
o: HttpOnly
Secure
SameSite
Expires
data.e: The `SameSite` attribute (values like `Strict` or `Lax`) tells the browser whether to send cookies along with requests initiated by third-party websites.

data.q: What does the 'HttpOnly' flag on a cookie do?
o: It forces the cookie to be sent over HTTPS only
It prevents JavaScript from accessing the cookie via document.cookie
It makes the cookie expire as soon as the browser is closed
It prevents the cookie from being sent to the server
data.e: `HttpOnly` is a vital defense against XSS; even if a script is successfully injected, it cannot steal the session cookie because the JS engine is blocked from reading it.

o: A way to check if a user is human
A security feature that allows browsers to verify that fetched resources (like CDNs) haven't been manipulated
An encryption method for local storage
A tool for minifying JavaScript files
data.e: SRI uses cryptographic hashes (the `integrity` attribute) to ensure that if a file on a CDN is hacked or altered, the browser will refuse to execute it.

o: The website can only be accessed via a VPN
The browser should only communicate with the server using HTTPS, never HTTP
All images must be loaded from the same domain
The server is protected against SQL injection
data.e: HSTS tells the browser to automatically convert all attempts to access the site using HTTP to HTTPS requests, protecting against man-in-the-middle attacks.

data.q: What is the 'X-Frame-Options' header used for?
o: To speed up the rendering of iframes
To prevent 'Clickjacking' by controlling whether a page can be embedded in an iframe
To allow multiple windows to share the same state
To set the dimensions of the browser window
data.e: Clickjacking involves overlaying a transparent iframe over a legitimate site. `X-Frame-Options: DENY` or `SAMEORIGIN` prevents the site from being framed maliciously.

data.q: What is the difference between 'Stored XSS' and 'Reflected XSS'?
o: Stored XSS happens in the browser; Reflected happens on the server
Stored XSS is saved in the database; Reflected is 'bounced' off a URL parameter or form input
Stored XSS only affects CSS; Reflected affects JavaScript
There is no practical difference
data.e: Stored (or Persistent) XSS is the most dangerous because the payload is saved on the server (e.g., in a comment section) and served to every user who views the page.

data.q: What security risk is associated with `target="_blank"` on a link?
o: It allows the new page to access the original page's window object via `window.opener`
It causes the browser to download viruses automatically
It bypasses the Same-Origin Policy
It disables the back button for the user
data.e: Without `rel="noopener"`, the newly opened page can potentially redirect the original page to a phishing site using `window.opener.location`.
